newsitem.title: USA: Most class-action suits newly filed.
newsitem.headline: Most class-action suits newly filed.

text.p: Most of the class-action suits likely to be affected by Friday's agreement on tobacco litigation were filed in 13 states, Puerto Rico, and the District of Columbia and grow out of a national class-action lawsuit thrown out of court last year.
Two others in Miami, including one on behalf of people claiming injuries from secondhand cigarette smoke, were filed in the early 1990s by husband-and-wife lawyers Stanley and Susan Rosenblatt.
One of the Rosenblatt class-action suits, Norma Broin vs. Philip Morris et al, is now in jury selection and a trial in the $5 billion suit is likely to start in early July.
The Broin class action is on behalf of some 60,000 non-smoking flight attendants who have tobacco-related illnesses allegedly caused by the cigarette smoke of passengers aboard U.S. airlines.
The Rosenblatts' other case, on behalf of sick Florida smokers, is scheduled for trial in September.
The other 15 lawsuits were filed after a federal judge ruled last year that a national class-action lawsuit on behalf of millions of sick smokers was too unwieldy for trial.
